Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

As Debbie said, " You either believe it or you don't....... .."

These peop=
le (who either believe, or don't) can safely ignore my points.=A0 I am not =
addressing those who have either decided that this is all impossible, or th=
at this is all beyond question.=A0 I am only speaking to those with open mi=
nds as regarding what is proven and what is not, who can move around in the=
ir stance, who can question their beliefs, and who are willing to listen to=
 theories from all over the spectrum of evidence, science, theory, practice=
, and even belief.=A0 I am not really hopeful that those who either "believ=
e or don't" will find my points useful.

If I can't hear the voices Frank (=
or if I hear them different), that does not mean it is not real.=A0 If no o=
ne else, in an objective testing situation, can hear what you hear without =
being told what it is first, that may not make it real or fake, but it does=
 suggest some interesting further testing is justified.=A0 

But again, not=
 for those who feel it is black and white.=A0 Now if you think " You either=
 believe it or you don't....... .."

=A0




    
                   So if you can't=
 hear the voices that makes it universal that no one can hear it, or it's n=
ot real? If you went by your test of determining if audio was real, they yo=
u'd have to reject all the music and speech in the world that everyone hear=
s different, and you'd have to constantly qyestion what your wife just said=
. It's subjective, and that's as good as it going to get. If you want scien=
tifc, go join JREF.



The fact is, the boxes and related devices work, and=
 some out there don't like it. 



F-S



--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com, =
"Rick" <rasterer@.. .> wrote:

>

> Unfortunately, the examples used were p=
roblematic.

> 

> You might notice they either played the EVP, then told t=
he audience what the they were supposed to hear, and then played it again. =
 Or told the audience what they were supposed to hear first.  They never ju=
st played the sound (without the leading questions), and gave the audience =
some time to decide what it was saying on their own.

> 

> So while the hi=
story at the start was interesting, all the examples were, sadly, more exam=
ples of how people can fool themselves with  pareidolia, than examples of s=
pirit communications.

> 

> 

> Note also, this also explains why prerecor=
ding noises, and using them later for the source of a Q/A session, still wo=
rks.  It's a tricky explanation when trying to explain how spirits are 'cha=
nging' the sounds at session time.  But it is an easy explanation that it w=
ouldn't matter whether the sounds were live or recorded, if it was just peo=
ple hearing what they wanted to hear.

> 

> I realize that many people are=
n't out to prove anything, and that's fine: but in this case, it seemed a p=
oint of the interview was to demonstrate the efficacy of the box.  In this =
case it would be better to either state they do not expect their examples t=
o be prove anything, or if they expect to convince an audience, to use bett=
er testing of their results, and less leading of the audience.

> 

> imho

> 

>
